pullRequest.body:
We add various results about the third cyclotomic field needed to prove flt3.

From the flt3 project at LFTCM2024.

---

### PR summary [f68c15cbae](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13798/commits/f68c15cbae53911c1cb412324d8f9b777008d0bb)

#### Import changes

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.Fintype | 715 | 797 | +82 (+11.47%) |
| Mathlib.NumberTheory.Cyclotomic.Three | 2128 | 2129 | +1 (+0.05%) |

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Finset.univ_of_card_le_three`
`+ Finset.univ_of_card_le_two`
`+ card_quotient_toInteger_sub_one`
`+ charP_of_card_eq_prime`
`+ coe_eta`
`+ coe_toInteger`
`+ cube_sub_one_eq_mul`
`+ eta_sq_add_eta_add_one`
`+ finite_quotient_toInteger_sub_one`
`+ lambda_dvd_mul_sub_one_mul_sub_eta_add_one`
`+ lambda_dvd_or_dvd_sub_one_or_dvd_add_one`
`+ lambda_pow_four_dvd_cube_add_one_of_dvd_add_one`
`+ lambda_pow_four_dvd_cube_sub_one_of_dvd_sub_one`
`+ lambda_pow_four_dvd_cube_sub_one_or_add_one_of_lambda_not_dvd`
`+ ringEquivOfPrime`
`+ ringEquivOfPrime_eq_ringEquiv`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

:v: riccardobrasca can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9660348640/job/26645728460)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9660348640/job/26645728730)

Lgtm, thanks! 

maintainer merge

LGTM with Johan's comment, thanks!

bors d+

Lgtm, thanks! 

maintainer merge

LGTM with Johan's comment, thanks!

bors d+

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ k) : Fintype (𝓞 K ⧸ Ideal.span {hζ.toInteger - 1}) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ k) : ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ k) : ```
Should `p.Prime -> Fintype.card R = p -> CharP R p` be its own lemma?
Why not, thanks!

I've added it to `Mathlib/Algebra/CharP/CharAndCard.lean`, that is not imported by this file (it seems a better place to have it). Rather then messing up the imports I think we can just keep this proof as it is.
The other lemmas in this file take `[Fact p.Prime]`, should this one do the same?
Capital T for toInteger, I think
Have you considered using Nat.card?
Ah yes, this is a good idea, to avoid the `Fintype` instance. Thanks!
eta_sq... rather than eta_eq
Why do you need the type annotation?

Because `hζ.toInteger_isPrimitiveRoot` says that `hζ.toInteger ^ ↑3 = 1`, where `3 : ℕ+` but in the goal there is a `3 : ℕ`. The general statement of `toInteger_isPrimitiveRoot` is I think correct (positivity is needed in the definition of `toInteger`).
There might be a specialized mul_dvd_mul_left (or right, who knows)
I'd use h.neg_right
We must have s \subset univ as a lemma, no?
Would it be possible to add the uniqueness statement, so that if `e` is an equivalence between two such rings then `e=ringEquivOfPrime`?

Rather than duplicating all the results about `ZMod.ringEquiv` (uniqueness, reflexivity, transitivity etc), I've added a comment in the definition of `ringEquivOfPrime` to explain how to turn it into `ZMod.ringEquiv` (the results for which are already there).
Why not adding a `lambda` in front of the first `dvd`? Also, shouldn't this be also `private`?

I fixed the name. It cannot be `private` since it will be needed in the proof of flt3, in another file (I will make sure to make "public" only the results I really need in the other file, maybe only this one).
But if you make it private and then prepend the namespace, wouldn't this work?
Are you thinking about `protected`? AFAIK the purpose of `private` is to make lemmas "invisible" in other files (or sections, or whatever).

Oh right, I had `protected` in mind, and I have the same mental image of `private` as you have, so I finally agree that this should not be `private` (but hopefully in a namespace - I am not with VSCode now and cannot check).
Yes, everything is in a (very specific) namespace.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hR : Fintype.card R = p) : ringEquivOfPrime R hp hR = ringEquiv R hR := rfl ```

```suggestion
  let _ : Ring (𝓞 K ⧸ Ideal.span {λ}) := CommRing.toRing -- to speed up instance synthesis
  let _ : AddGroup (𝓞 K ⧸ Ideal.span {λ}) := AddGroupWithOne.toAddGroup -- dito
  have := Finset.mem_univ (Ideal.Quotient.mk (Ideal.span {λ}) x)
  have h3 : Fintype.card (𝓞 K ⧸ Ideal.span {λ}) = 3 := by
    rw [← Nat.card_eq_fintype_card, hζ.card_quotient_toInteger_sub_one (by decide),
      hζ.norm_toInteger_sub_one_of_prime_ne_two' (by decide)]
    simp only [PNat.val_ofNat, Nat.cast_ofNat, Int.reduceAbs]
  rw [Finset.univ_of_card_eq_three h3] at this
  simp only [Finset.mem_insert, Finset.mem_singleton] at this
  rcases this with (h | h | h)
  · left
    exact Ideal.mem_span_singleton.1 <| Ideal.Quotient.eq_zero_iff_mem.1 h
  · right; left
    refine Ideal.mem_span_singleton.1 <| Ideal.Quotient.eq_zero_iff_mem.1 ?_
    rw [RingHom.map_sub, h, RingHom.map_one, sub_self]
  · right; right
    refine Ideal.mem_span_singleton.1 <| Ideal.Quotient.eq_zero_iff_mem.1 ?_
    rw [RingHom.map_add, h, RingHom.map_one, add_left_neg]
```
This one was quite slow. Adding the two explicit instances makes it reasonably fast.

```suggestion
  rw [eta_sq]
  ring
```
The private lemma `eta_sq` must be good for something...
Maybe remove the private lemma instead; it does not seem to be used.

```suggestion
  rw [this, pow_succ]
```

```suggestion
    exact (neg_add' x 1).symm
```
Is it really an advantage?
I don't insist, but my feeling is that `ring` is overkill when it is just one simple lemma.
I see your point, and most probably agree with you. In general I find that `ring` has the advantage of being less affected by library changes, but if it is just one lemma it looks like an overkill.

```suggestion
  convert (lambda_pow_four_dvd_cube_sub_one_of_dvd_sub_one hζ h).neg_right using 1
```
The parens around `h | h | h` are not necessary.
The parens around `H | H | H` are not necessary.
Not sure if it will ever be useful... but I guess you can weaken the `= 3` to `\le 3`. Idem for the `= 2` above.
Why not!
More note to self than anything to do in this PR: I feel like this should be `aesop`able...

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Mathlib.NumberTheory.Cyclotomic.Three): add various results
